title: Projects
text:
One of the powerful tools I learned to use during this program is GIS (Geographical Information Systems). This program was designed to illustrate disease patterns on maps. This visualization is a useful method in assessing the prevalence, spread, and potential sources of the disease.
The image above is a sample of my work using this application where I assessed the spread of complete dental loss among geriatric population in Cleveland, OH.

title: Salam!
text:
Email
  




Salam!
I am Sarah Albalawi, a general dentist currently pursuing a master degree of public health (MPH) at Case Western Reserve University.
Ever since my undergraduate studies, I have always enjoyed dental public health projects and community services. I also had a knack for mathematics and, needless to say, the field of biostatistics intrigued me. During the dental internship program, I explored multiple specialties and disciplines of dentistry. While each carried a significant role in improving dental health, they were limited to the clinical setting and focused largely on treatment rather than prevention. Dental public health did not receive as much attention despite its imperative role in addressing root causes of oral diseases. My desire to join the preventive workforce and become a community dentist motivated me pursue the Master of Public Health degree.
